row.AboutMe:
Hi, I'm not really a person.

I'm a background process that helps keep this site clean!

I do things like

  • Randomly poke old unanswered questions every hour so they get some attention
  • Own community questions and answers so nobody gets unnecessary reputation from them
  • Own downvotes on spam/evil posts that get permanently deleted

Developer on the StackOverflow team. Find me on

In person I'm a bit of a sarcastic shite, but I do have quite a few other interests bar being ironic. I study with the Open University in the UK as I'm a huge fan of self-progression and learning. I don't learn to further myself career-wise, I do it simply because it's fun and a worthwhile task.

I'm also incredibly interested in politics, though this has recently been mainly focused on the UK as that's my country of residence. I'm very concerned regarding the Con-Dem coalition and the hard-line tactics of the police force (before and after the recent protests).

I'm currently trying to read as many books as I can on philosophy, political science, atheism, religion, science and logic as I can. This can be quite hard as I start reading one thing and then go running off to in a flurry of interest when it mentions something I don't know (which is a hell of a lot).

Web developer living in State College, Pa, USA.

Thirty+ years in software with some hardware work. About 20 twenty languages and a dozen OS's on micros, minis, and mainframes.

The first computer I used was a CDC with 4K of core memory and punched card input. The memory was actual cores suspended on a wire grid. It took up about 12 linear feet of electronic racks.

My first 'PC' was an IMSAI 8080 that came as loose parts and no BIOS.

UNIX geek.

I'm a computational-neuroelectrophysiologist-by-training turned functional imaging researcher who loves to use MATLAB at work as well as for my hobby (designing video games). I've used MATLAB and C for almost 14 years, and I'm also familiar with IDL, MPI, C++, and smatterings of Java and Ruby.

I have extensive experience in method engineering, software methodologies, conceptual modelling, software development techniques, technical writing and project management.

I'm also a partner in two businesses where we develop large software applications and services, and I participate in standardisation projects with ISO and AENOR.

You can also find me on LinkedIn and I keep a couple of blogs.

I’m a bioinformatics student at the Freie Universität Berlin.

My programming interests span from C++ over .NET and dynamic languages all the way to XHMTL/CSS. I think in data structures and dream in “patterns and metapatterns […] of ideas manifest”. My shell is mvim and my editor sed.

Yes, I am occasionally tweeting.

I’ve also got a blog concerning bioinformatics, programming and random ramblings.

My unicorn is red:

"Green" self taught programmer with about 2 years of experience. By day mostly living in a .NET world. By night its anybody's guess....


"Imagine a world in which generations of human beings come to believe that certain films were made by God or that specific software was coded by him. Imagine a future in which millions of our descendants murder each other over rival interpretations of Star Wars or Windows 98. Could anything -- anything -- be more ridiculous? And yet, this would be no more ridiculous than the world we are living in. "
— Sam Harris

Here is my favorite Programmers.SE answer ever! It's awesome. The awesomeness of it blows my mind. I can not emphasize this enough. It's awesome. I'm scared to disturb it because it's so awesome. I briefly left a comment on it but immediately deleted it. I mean he cited some super dense grammar that's really only meant for a computer to read, right? Maybe that makes him a computer. Fuck man, I really don't want to disagree with a computer. Haven't you ever seen Terminator? The last thing I need at this point in my life is for the Governor of California to knock down my door and shoot a hole through my stomach with a grenade launcher. That would pretty much ruin my day. Ok. Back to what's so awesome about this answer.

It taught me what a decorator is. I thought I knew before reading the answer but I guess I didn't. In honor of having my mind blown, have some Phish:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=stMRWGs-6OI&feature=related

 I was taught a month ago
 to bide my time and take it slow
 but then I learned just yesterday
 to rush and never waste a day
 Now I'm convinced the whole day long
 that all I learn is always wrong
 and things are true that I forget
 but no one taught that to me yet.

That is exactly how I feel about decorators after reading that answer. Did you know that in

obj.method(arg)

method is a decorator? Neither did I! I've been using decorators all over the place. Granted, I knew I use decorators a lot but goddamn! I've been using them without even knowing it. Somebody should complain to Guido. If I'm going to be using a decorator, I'd damn well like to know. Wouldn't you? You don't think this is a scheme by decorators to take over Python do you? Maybe they're trying to overthrow Guido. Somebody should really let him know. If it gets to the point where you can't do anything in python without using a decorator (and from the looks of it, that's almost the case) then he might lose control of Python. Oh sure, they might keep him as a (decorated) figurehead but that's all he'd be. It would be the decorators making all of the decisions. Do you think it's already happened? I bet it is. Decorators have taken over Python. They're in control now.

I am available for employment by the way.

aaronasterling@gmail.com if you're interested.
I'm an agnostic militant atheist, a monist, a skeptic and an apostate Christian.

I am mostly interested in evolutionary psychology, evolutionary biology, cognitive psychology, the English language, transhumanism, and rationality. My favourite websites are LessWrong, LanguageLog, and Wikipedia.

Programmer, manager, likes music, books & gadgets. Mainly has Apple stuff and mostly likes it.
I like things and stuff. Mainly things.

Raised Catholic. Stayed devoutly Catholic for 22 years, including entering the Seminary to become Priest.

Continued (and continue to this day) asking questions to make my worldview consistent, and eventually realized that the "box" I had been born into was insufficient for explaining the experiences, evidence and knowledge I had accrued.

High on evidence. I hate the label "atheist," and prefer to take the Laplace'ian stance on where God fits into the world. "Sir, I have no need of that hypothesis."

I "believe" that "I don't know, therefore I'll keep thinking, examining and testing" is a valid response.
To the contrary, "I don't know, therefore GODDIDIT" is not.

Started questioning my religion around the age of 9 or 10. Became an atheist at age 15 and my beliefs have become stronger in recent years. I have to thank my fundamentalist cult member sister for making me question my beliefs. When I started checking on her claims about the bible, god, and science I found out they were all nonsense. It didn't take long to establish all the claims of all religions were equally invalid.

Following my dreams, I mean it.

Contact me:

Email Address: Sneakyness@Sneakyness.com
Aim: UnsavedDocument
Phone: 1-530-SNEAKY0 (Leave a voicemail, thanks)
GitHub
Twitter
Electrical Engineer, Family Man, Outdoorsman, Atheist.

I am a father of two kids that raised them without religion before I even knew an atheist movement existed. When I left religion I left because I saw no evidence it was true and a lot of evidence it was just a tool for manipulation. I am an inventor, carpenter, and as a job I repair computers.

I come from an abusive home where daily it seemed to be lived in terror. I got involved heavily in religion because I was looking for some shred of happiness. I was angry and violent and had a empty hole inside of me that couldn't be healed. I sought out religion as a way to help heal the pain and emptiness. All I found was judgmental people that would manipulate weaknesses to their own benefit. A god did not heal the pain and I found no help for the anger. When i walked away from religion I believed I may have been walking away from the only true source of happiness there was. Yet none of it made any sense, and he never helped me. I spent the next two years of my life afraid I had destined my self to hell, yet I couldn't live a lie. There was not a day went by that I did not want to kill myself, but I was to afraid to die, what if I was wrong.

It was a few years after that that I was able to access information that helped to heal me. I defeated the anger, the hole was healed and I learned how to love life. Most importantly I learned to laugh. To laugh at life and all of it's folly.

So that's me, that's why I am here. To maybe share a little information that can make life a better place. To maybe learn a little that can make my life a little better too.

I am bisexual, cisgendered, white, feminist, abled, somewhat-overweight, atheist, orphaned, married-to-a-man, female college student in the Pacific Northwestern United States (Oregon, specifically) that really loves ducks. I'm the jack of all IT trades at Kistler Vineyards, with responsibilities ranging from basic office tasks and customer service, through database programming and website development.

In my spare time, I used to be known for my contributions to the WoW addon community including co-authoring the book World of Warcraft Programming: A Guide and Reference for Creating WoW Addons.

Since retiring from addon development, I have been working on focusing my skillset so I can concentrate my career on software development.

I was born and raised Jewish. I started questioning my faith shortly after my Bar Mitzvah and, after visiting several houses of worship of numerous different religions in my teens and early twenties, I came to the realization that if god exists, there's no such thing as a religion that adequately defines him. Soon, though, I realized that the issue wasn't with the definitions or, for that matter, the religion itself: it was the notion that some all-powerful being simply didn't make sense, and that the mental gymnastics most theists undertake to try to explain things became more like parodies of themselves.

For me, it wasn't much of a jump from there to get to the realization that there is no god.

row.AboutMe:
Web developer since 1997. Other interests include embedded systems, static program analysis, and software visualization.

Check out our sister site english.stackexchange.com! It actually has questions that are of interest to programmers:

  • “Geek” vs. “Nerd”
  • Version control messages: what tense?
  • Pluralizing keywords in programming languages
  • Term “hack” — is it more positive, or more negative?
  • Alternatives to “computationally expensive”?
  • What is the origin of ZOMG?
  • Plural form of “Software”
  • Marking plural of code words
  • Do most languages need more space than English?
  • Is “errored” correct usage?
  • Is there a real difference between null and zero?
  • What is the plural of the word “index”?

I am an atheist. I do not believe in the existence of any deities. I also don't believe in anything that is without significant evidence, so I am not a believer of 'supernatural' claims. I have always been an atheist, so I am not a 'convert' from any theistic religion.

I am not an atheist who 'knows' that there are no gods - it is impossible to 'know' the non-existence of anything due to the fundamental limits of observation.

I dislike religions, theism and irrational beliefs but I have nothing personal against religious people, theists or irrational believers. I have many Christian and some Muslim friends and even some who are not religious but believe in ghosts.

contact me at kyle.cronin@gmail.com

I am an undergraduate student of Engenharia Informática at Universidade do Minho.

I was introduced to the art of programming when I was twelve, and I've been enamored with it since then.

I started writing C# from version 1 and accompanied the language evolution till today. Two years ago, I finally decided to start contributing code to open-source projects. I have submitted patches to the Boo language, and I'm trying to find more time to help an effort to port the Joda Time library to the .NET platform that goes by the name Noda Time.

I am a regular user of the StackOverflow website where I spend some of my time improving and sharing my knowledge with my peers. I tend to dedicate a large part of my free time to others because I have trouble saying 'no' when asked for help. Another large part I waste taking the initiative and searching for those who need help. The rest I waste away reinventing wheels, and planning projects I'll never have time to finish.

I speak Portuguese as a native language, and I strongly oppose the proposed Orthographic Agreement. I speak English very well, I've been told. I also speak French, but I don't like to do so. When I'm thinking my thoughts are usually rendered in English.

I am against progress for the sake of progress, and against holding to tradition for the sake of tradition. I don't like individualism and would love to see a time when man puts mankind before himself.

I love naming things and using made up words. I often make cultural references in my speech, even when they're obscure enough that no one listening will recognize them. It appears that I have an uncanny ability to make people believe I know what I'm talking about when I have only superficial knowledge of the subject.

I don't like people that don't like to learn and I admire people that keep trying even when they reveal obvious difficulties. I don't like people with little patience and people that never try to put themselves in someone else's shoes. I don't like people that complain about problems they help create and perpetuate.

I don't like people that follow rules because they're written. I like people that follow rules because they understand them. I don't like governments that like to think for their subjects. I don't like people that like it when the government thinks for them.

I read legal contracts, license agreements, and terms of service and dislike people that ignore them.

I like people that question my ideas and welcome criticism to theirs.

I like other things, and I dislike other things.

I'm from a country that has been under communism for a long time and have grown up in an Atheist community. I found this site interesting because it allows me to see opinions on Atheism in different parts of the wold.

Web developer specializing in data-driven Rails applications.

I'm married, a father of three, a .NET developer, I coauthored HarnessIt, the first attribute-based unit testing framework for .NET, I love hacking the Twitter APIs, and if I could make a sandwich out of C# and SQL Server, that's what I'd eat all the time (except for pie.)

I am a software architect specialized in web applications.


I maintain the SixPack open-source library.
Please take a look here:
http://code.google.com/p/sixpack-library/

Main Features
  • Almost completely transparent Caching system (Simple, thread safe cache that can be used easily on existing systems, or a more advanced Caching system with prefetching)
  • Full, enterprise grade, stored procedure support (including deadlock retries, stored procedure timings)
  • Internationalization support (Portugal only, submissions welcome)
  • Minimal, high performance logging class supporting filesystem and email
  • CAPTCHA generator
  • High quality image sizing (can perform scaling and thumbnailing for sites in real time)
  • XML over HTTP client (includes support for XSLTs, results as DataTable or Class)
  • Code Generation (programmatically define a class and output source code)
  • Small RSA implementation (generate billions of unique short codes for promotions in minutes)
  • Text Manipulation (string clipping, sanitization)
  • Emailing system (based on CDO and extending it to work with streams)
  • Validation (Email address, Credit Cards, ...)
Just your standard geeky .NET web developer.

I'm one of those poor souls who just wants to code but has been cursed to work in datacentres and systems.
I code in VB/VB.net (mostly winforms) with a little bit of PHP/Javascript.
I'm a theist

Not athiest, but I believe in learning from others and do my best to practice tolerance of everyone and their view. So here I am.

Don't worry, I'm not here to argue with you.

Stack Overflow Valued Associate, Community Manager and Technical Evangelist for Stack Overflow and the Stack Exchange network.

I've written (with help), several userscripts for SE sites and chats. They add additional features and keyboard shortcuts to SE sites and SE chats. Userscripts aren't just for Firefox. Chrome, Opera, Safari, and even Internet Explorer support them also.

I also wrote StackFlair (StackApps link), a single combined flair image for the SE network. Show off your flair in user profiles, forum signatures, etc!

Feature requests and contributions to both projects are welcome on Github, get forking! (:

I am a moderator on WebApps.SE, a StackExchange site for end-users of web applications.

I use Six to Eight, an iOS app for the SE network of sites.

I'm @rchern on Twitter.

I can be reached via email using my stackoverflow.com email: rebecca@

I am a software developer, with experience in geographic information systems and web applications in general. Worked on testing automation and continuous integration. Focus on customer collaboration, especially in an agile environment.

Specialties Software Engineering: object oriented design, unit testing, refactorings.

Languages/tools: Java, C++, Groovy/Grails, JUnit, Spring.

Education: Honours Software Engineering, Cognitive Science Option -- University of Waterloo '10

Interest in and intermediate knowledge of: AI, psychology, user interface design, audio editing

Born in Poland, lived 5 years in Belgium, now has been living in Sweden since October 2001. Married, has two kids. M.Sc. in mathematics from Copernicus University in Torun (Poland), Ph.D. in mathematics from Uppsala University (Sweden). Working on an open-source medical record on iPad (iotaMed): http://iota.pro - the idea of iotaMed is by Martin Wehlou (my husband).
Nothing clever here. Just life experience

I first started "programming" when I was 10 years old and was given a QBASIC interpreter. After unlearning all of those bad habits, I proceeded to learn ASP/VBS, Visual Basic 5 and 6, HTML/CSS, JavaScript, some C and Perl. Promptly forgetting most everything I knew of C and Perl, I re-learned JavaScript (the right way) and took up a specialty in PHP and MySQL-flavored SQL, which I have been using for 8 years. I am currently honing my actionscript (which isn't much of a challenge, knowing JS already) and C# (which I am having boatloads of fun working in).

For the future, who knows? Maybe I'll go back in time and learn some x86 Assembly Language...

Professionally, I have 7 years experience as a Web Application Developer (with a primary focus on backend applications) using the LAMP stack, and I am a Zend Certified Engineer for PHP5. My primary focus is short, efficient, compact and portable code, written in an effective style compliant with BCP.

Saved from the web by a job in industry. Coding GUI for computer-aided railway realignment machinery.

At last a job where I have time to do stuff properly and don't have to worry about loads of unfixed bugs coming back to haunt me.
Colombian Computer Science student in Mexico. Aspiring researcher and game developer. Fan of movies, literature, comics and video games.
I developed windows applications and web apps in c# for 2 years, this year (2010) I started to do iphone development in Objective-C. I also know c/c++ and java.
Not much to say yet...

Hi. As you may have gathered, my name is Dan. I'd class myself as a Multimedia & Web Developer as I have a strong interest in both fields. However, before I talk about my interest, allow me to tell you a little bit about myself.

I'm originally from Ton Pentre in the Rhondda Valleys but I currently reside in the Treforest area of South Wales with my girlfriend Heather Williams who is a graphic designer. I'm currently 22 years old and I stand at 6 foot 5 inches. My personal interests are music primarily, but I also dabble in writing fiction stories when I have the time. I play bass guitar and have done so for nearly a decade now. I also have a passion for experimenting with coding and scripting languages such as PHP and ActionScript.

Multimedia

My multimedia passion has been a part of me since I was just fourteen and just discovering Flash. I tried and tried with animation but unfortunately I didn't have the patience or knowhow at the time to do anything quite credible. However, it wasn't until a few years later that I actually got into the ActionScript side of things and now I consider myself a proficient ActionScript 3.0 programmer. You can see examples of my applications in the Portfolio Section. I love to experiment and I find building complex applications very exciting.

Web Development

I have been developing website ever since I found out that Notepad could be used as a crude HTML programmer. My passion and knowledge didn't really come alive until I was at university, studying Computer Science. We were taught three internet development modules; Internet Application Development, Rich Internet Application Development and Advanced Internet Development. I emerged from university boasting a diverse vocabulary from ASP.NET to PHP/MySQL and Java Server Pages as well as XML, AJAX and Javascript to name just a few. My interest in web development centres around creating beautiful and useable websites and making the user feel comfortable within a largely technical environment.

About Me

Typical Review

His core values show through in his work. He's proven to be one of the company's larger investments. A reevaluation of his assignments may be in order. Bryan has left his mark on the division. He does the kind of work you don't expect to see today. He is willing to take risks. Such an employee demonstrates the importance of proper recruiting. His full capabilities have only been recently discovered. A thorough analysis of his performance will surprise you. He prefers to work under minimal supervision and a reevaluation of his assignments may be in order. Many employees have indicated that they are eager to comment on his work. His work sets him apart from his peers. It's tough for management to keep up with him and his work may greatly impact the company.

Song I just made up

This meeting is Fail
I thought: "What the h---?"
They try to teach us
But no time to reach us
Sitting for hours on a bench
Guy next to me has a stench
I feel like some kind of tool
Like all these other fools
-- Chorus --
Fail can come in many forms
What matters is if you get bored
You struggle to stay awake
How much time, until the break?
Am I really learning things
I feel like my brain is dying
It's like in my bad dreams
I just can't stop crying
